awd_titl_txt: NetSE: Medium: Collaborative Research: Towards Human- Network Interaction (HNI) for the Home
awd_abstract_narration:
As networks move outside professionally-managed environments to end-users become tasked with deploying, managing, securing, and troubleshooting their networks. Evidence shows that end-users cannot manage networks, and their rejection of these technologies represents a significant barrier to the adoption of advanced applications. This research will lower the barrier, by demonstrating how the challenges of human-network interaction must be solved with new technical approaches. Through empirical methods, we will produce datasets detailing the challenges, the needs of the users who both manage and live with such networks, and the opportunities for network design. We will develop an initial architecture that centralizes many network functions. This research will extend this architecture and deploy and evaluate it in people?s homes. The results will produce sound, generally-applicable principles for more usable network design. These principles will be particularly applicable to contexts where no formal network administrator is present.

Our work benefits society in three distinct ways. Usable home networking is on the critical path for computing research innovation. Research results will teach the next generation of engineers how to design usable networking. The integration of usability concerns into the core of computing reflects the growing diversity of careers in IT, and opens up the possibility of increasing the participation of women and minorities in computing.

por.por_cntn:
This project has explored the creation of new tools to let unskilled users better manage and maintain their networks, for example, in the home setting. Increasingly, broadband Internet access is becoming a requirement for daily life, yet home users may have neither the time nor inclination to manage and secure their home networks. This project has thus used a variety of user-centered methodologies to create guidelines for the design of home networking tools and to put these in practice through a variety of applications built on a custom firmware platform for common home routers. 

 

One of the primary outcomes of this project is uCap, a bandwidth management tool aimed at home users to allow them to better manage and allocate their Internet resources. uCap has been successfully deployed in a number of settings to test its efficacy and revise its design. 

 

The software platform developed as a part of this project can potentially be used for other applications in homes and communities as well. For example, the project has developed proof-of-concept demonstrations of using the home router as a sensor; such a sensor might be used to build models of activity in the home, and could potentially be used for more effective energy utilization or home security applications. This platform has also been used to develop a proof-of-concept wireless mesh network infrastructure intended to connect groups of homes together into a community network. Such a network might facilitate information sharing among nodes in the network, while its decentralized architecture provides greater privacy guarantees than a traditional Internet-based architecture.
